info.text: The default category for questions shared in context 'ExampleSpaces'.

questiontext.text: What does it mean for a number \(x\) to be a limit point of a sequence \((x_n)\)?

generalfeedback.text: The number \(x\) is a limit point of the sequence \((x_n)\) if there is a subsequence of \((x_n)\) that converges to \(x\).

questiontext.text:
Give an example of a sequence which has:

  • 0 as a limit point:

    \(a_n=\) [[validation:ans1]][[input:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

  • 0 as a limit point but not a limit:

    \(b_n=\) [[validation:ans2]][[input:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  • 3 as a limit point but not a limit:

    \(c_n=\) [[validation:ans3]][[input:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

  • 3 as a limit point but not a limit, and no term of the sequence is equal to 3:

    \(d_n=\) [[validation:ans4]][[input:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: \(a_n={@ans1@}\) does have 0 as a limit point.

falsefeedback.text: STACK could not find a limit point of 0 in your sequence.
STACK was not able to compute with your example - it will need to be checked by a teacher.

truefeedback.text: \(b_n={@ans2@}\) does have 0 as a limit point.

falsefeedback.text: STACK could not find a limit point of 0 in your sequence.

truefeedback.text: However, it appears that 0 is the limit of the sequence -- the question asked for an example where 0 is not the limit.

falsefeedback.text: STACK was not able to compute with your example - it will need to be checked by a teacher.

truefeedback.text: \(c_n={@ans3@}\) does have 3 as a limit point.

falsefeedback.text: STACK could not find a limit point of 3 in your sequence.

truefeedback.text: However, it appears that 3 is the limit of the sequence -- the question asked for an example where 3 is not the limit.

falsefeedback.text: STACK was not able to compute with your example - it will need to be checked by a teacher.

truefeedback.text: \(d_n={@ans4@}\) does have 3 as a limit point.

falsefeedback.text: STACK could not find a limit point of 3 in your sequence.

truefeedback.text: However, it appears that 3 is the limit of the sequence -- the question asked for an example where 3 is not the limit.
The question asked for a sequence where 3 does not appear as a term, but it seems that your example does have 3 as a term (the first few terms are {@sequenceify(terms4)@}).

falsefeedback.text: STACK was not able to compute with your example - it will need to be checked by a teacher.

name.text: Piecewise linear function A: given image

questiontext.text:
Drag the points so that the diagram shows the graph of a function \(f:[0,1]\to [0,1]\) with image \(\left[0,\frac12\right]\).

[[input:pwa_ans1]] [[validation:pwa_ans1]]

[[jsxgraph width='300px' height='300px']] // The values from the question text are saved in variable vars. // These are needed only if you want to "randomize" the diagram. // The random-values should be saved in a maxima-list and printed in a paragraph with the class "stack-variables". // Use the syntax {#list1#} to print the list as plain text. // You can use the attribute style="display:none;" to hide the list from students. // // Example:

{#list1#}

// var vars = []; // The answers from the answer-field are saved here. This is neede to save the 'state' of the diagram. var ans = []; // Shortcut for accessing the document. // var doc = window.parent.document; // For ILIAS var doc = document; // For Moodle /************************************************************************************************/ /* ONLY EDIT THE CODE BETWEEN THESE TWO STAR-LINES */ // Create the board and all elements // use vars[0], vars[1], etc. for accessing the values read from the question text. // // If you want to test the applet offline, you need to uncomment the next line. // var divid = "box"; var ans_input_id = "_pwa_ans1"; JXG.Options.axis.ticks.minorTicks = 0; var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, {boundingbox: [-0.1,1.1,1.1,-0.1], axis: true, grid: true, showNavigation: false, showCopyright:false, pan: {enabled: false}, zoom: {enabled: false}}); // The function createWithTimeout should include the elements that depend on values read from the question text. // These elements are created with a slight delay, so that the page has time to load. // Use vars[0], vars[1], etc. for accessing the values read from the question text. var createWithTimeout = function() { // none needed }; var pt_name = ["A", "B", "C", "D"]; var pt_initial_x = [0, 0.3, 0.7, 1]; var answer = []; var vline = []; for(let i of [0,1,2,3]) { answer.push(board.create('point', [pt_initial_x[i], 0], {color:'#003399',name: pt_name[i], showInfobox:false, snapToGrid:true, snapSizeX: 0.1, snapSizeY: 0.1})); } for(let i of [1,2,3]) { board.create('segment', [answer[i-1], answer[i]], {color:'#003399'}); } /************************************************************************************************/ // This function writes the x and y coordinates of the points in the array 'answer' to the field ans1 in the STACK-question. var defineValues = function() { var coords = []; for (let pts of answer) { coords.push([pts.X().toFixed(1), pts.Y().toFixed(1)]); }; console.log(coords); console.log(JSON.stringify(coords)); // since the rounding by toFixed makes the entries into strings, remove the " " now return JSON.stringify(coords).replace(/["]+/g, ''); }; // This function moves the points defined in array 'answer' to the positions based on the value in the answer field ans1. // This is needed for preserving the 'state' of the diagram ans happens after a student clicks "Check"/"Prüfen". var moveThingsAround = function() { var i = 0; for (let pts of answer) { pts.moveTo([ ans[2*i] , ans[2*i+1] ]); i++; }; }; // Read the values from the input-field ans1 to the array ans. // Then update the positions of the elements accordingly. if (doc.querySelector('input[id*='+ans_input_id+']').value!="") { ans = JSON.parse( doc.querySelector('[id*='+ans_input_id+']').value ).flat(); moveThingsAround(); }; // If anything changes on the board, write the values of the array vals to the input-field. // The answers are always written as a maxima type 'list'. board.on('update', function () { var vals = defineValues(); doc.querySelector('[id*='+ans_input_id+']').value = vals; }); [[/jsxgraph]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text: What you have drawn is not the graph of a function, since there is not a unique value for \(f(x)\) for each \(x\in[0,1]\).
The domain of your function is {@sa_domain@}, not \([0,1]\).
Your function has image {@sa_image@}.

name.text: Piecewise linear function B: given image, not injective

questiontext.text:

name.text: Piecewise linear function D: injective, not surjective, given range

questiontext.text:
Drag the points so that the diagram shows the graph of a function \(f:[0,1]\to [0,1]\) that is {@injective@}, not {@surjective@}, and passes through \(({@sequenceify(ptA)@})\) and \(({@sequenceify(ptB)@})\).

[[input:pwd_ans1]] [[validation:pwd_ans1]]

truefeedback.text: Your function has image \([0,1]\) so it is {@surjective@}, but the question asks for one which is not {@surjective@}.

falsefeedback.text: ✔ Your function has image {@sa_image@}, so it is not {@surjective@}.
Your function is not {@injective@}, but the question asks for one which is.
Your function does not seem to pass through {@ptA@}.
Your function does not seem to pass through {@ptB@}.
